metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Sorting Arrays
Array Sort Methods

content.html:
Alphabetic Sort

Array sort()
Array reverse()
Array toSorted()
Array toReversed()
Sorting Objects

See Also:

Basic Methods
Search Methods
Iteration Methods

Numeric Sort

Numeric Sort
Random Sort
Math.min()
Math.max()
Home made Min()
Home made Max()

content.text: Sorting an Array
The sort() method sorts an array alphabetically:
content.html: The sort() method sorts an array alphabetically:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.sort();

content.text: Reversing an Array
The reverse() method reverses the elements in an array:
content.html: The reverse() method reverses the elements in an array:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.reverse();

content.text: By combining sort() and reverse() , you can sort an array in descending order:
content.html: By combining sort() and reverse(), you can sort an array in descending order:

content.code_html:
const fruits = ["Banana", "Orange", "Apple", "Mango"];
fruits.sort();
fruits.reverse();

content.text: JavaScript Array toSorted() Method
ES2023 added the toSorted() method as a safe way to sort an array without altering the original array.
content.html: ES2023 added the toSorted() method as a safe way to sort an array without altering the original array.

content.text: The difference between toSorted() and sort() is that the first method creates a new array, keeping the original array unchanged, while the last method alters the original array.
content.html: The difference between toSorted() and sort() is that the first method creates a new array, keeping the original array unchanged, while the last method alters the original array.

content.code_html:
const months = ["Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"];
const sorted = months.toSorted();

content.text: JavaScript Array toReversed() Method
ES2023 added the toReversed() method as a safe way to reverse an array without altering the original array.
content.html: ES2023 added the toReversed() method as a safe way to reverse an array without altering the original array.

content.text: The difference between toReversed() and reverse() is that the first method creates a new array, keeping the original array unchanged, while the last method alters the original array.
content.html: The difference between toReversed() and reverse() is that the first method creates a new array, keeping the original array unchanged, while the last method alters the original array.

content.code_html:
const months = ["Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"];
const reversed = months.toReversed();

content.text: Numeric Sort
By default, the sort() function sorts values as strings .
content.html: By default, the sort() function sorts values as strings.

content.text: This works well for strings ("Apple" comes before "Banana").
content.html: This works well for strings ("Apple" comes before "Banana").

content.text: If numbers are sorted as strings, "25" is bigger than "100", because "2" is bigger than "1".
content.html: If numbers are sorted as strings, "25" is bigger than "100", because "2" is bigger than "1".

content.text: Because of this, the sort() method will produce incorrect result when sorting numbers.
content.html: Because of this, the sort() method will produce incorrect result when sorting numbers.

content.text: You can fix this by providing a compare function :
content.html: You can fix this by providing a compare function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return a - b});

content.code:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return a - b});

syntax_highlighting.text:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return a - b});

content.code_html:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return a - b});

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return a - b});

content.text: Use the same trick to sort an array descending:
content.html: Use the same trick to sort an array descending:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return b - a});

content.code:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return b - a});

syntax_highlighting.text:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return b - a});

content.code_html:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return b - a});

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return b - a});

content.text: The Compare Function
The purpose of the compare function is to define an alternative sort order.
content.html: The purpose of the compare function is to define an alternative sort order.

content.text: The compare function should return a negative, zero, or positive value, depending on the arguments:
content.html: The compare function should return a negative, zero, or positive value, depending on the arguments:

content.code_html: function(a, b){return a - b}

content.text: When the sort() function compares two values, it sends the values to the compare function, and sorts the values according to the returned (negative, zero, positive) value.
content.html: When the sort() function compares two values, it sends the values to the compare function, and sorts the values according to the returned (negative, zero, positive) value.

content.text: If the result is negative, a is sorted before b .
content.html: If the result is negative, a is sorted before b.

content.text: If the result is positive, b is sorted before a .
content.html: If the result is positive, b is sorted before a.

content.text: If the result is 0, no changes are done with the sort order of the two values.
content.html: If the result is 0, no changes are done with the sort order of the two values.

content.text: Example:
content.html: Example:

content.text: The compare function compares all the values in the array, two values at a time (a, b) .
content.html: The compare function compares all the values in the array, two values at a time (a, b).

content.text: When comparing 40 and 100, the sort() method calls the compare function(40, 100).
content.html: When comparing 40 and 100, the sort() method calls the compare function(40, 100).

content.text: The function calculates 40 - 100 (a - b) , and since the result is negative (-60), the sort function will sort 40 as a value lower than 100.
content.html: The function calculates 40 - 100 (a - b), and since the result is negative (-60),  the sort function will sort 40 as a value lower than 100.

content.text: You can use this code snippet to experiment with numerically and alphabetically sorting:
content.html: You can use this code snippet to experiment with numerically and alphabetically sorting:

content.code_html:
<button onclick="myFunction1()">Sort Alphabetically</button>
<button onclick="myFunction2()">Sort Numerically</button>

<p id="demo"></p>

<script>
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = points;

function myFunction1() {
  points.sort();
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = points;
}

function myFunction2() {
  points.sort(function(a, b){return a - b});
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = points;
}
</script>

content.text: Sorting an Array in Random Order
Using a sort function, like explained above, you can sort an numeric array in random order
content.html: Using a sort function, like explained above, you can sort an numeric array in random order

content.code_html:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(){return 0.5 - Math.random()});

content.text: The Fisher Yates Method
The points.sort() method in the example above is not accurate. It will favor some numbers over others.
content.html: The points.sort() method in the example above is not accurate. It will favor some numbers over others.

content.text: The most popular correct method, is called the Fisher Yates shuffle, and was introduced in data science as early as 1938!
content.html: The most popular correct method, is called the Fisher Yates shuffle, and was introduced in data science as early as 1938!

content.text: In JavaScript the method can be translated to this:
content.html: In JavaScript the method can be translated to this:

content.code_html:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];

for (let i = points.length -1; i > 0; i--) {
  let j = Math.floor(Math.random() * (i+1));
  let k = points[i];
  points[i] = points[j];
  points[j] = k;
}

content.text: Find the Lowest (or Highest) Array Value
There are no built-in functions for finding the max or min value in an array.
content.html: There are no built-in functions for finding the max or min value in an array.

content.text: To find the lowest or highest value you have 3 options:
content.html: To find the lowest or highest value you have 3 options:

content.text: Find Min or Max with sort()
After you have sorted an array, you can use the index to obtain the highest and lowest values.
content.html: After you have sorted an array, you can use the index to obtain the highest and lowest values.

content.text: Sort Ascending:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // now points[0] contains the lowest value
// and points[points.length-1] contains the highest value

syntax_highlighting.text: // now points[0] contains the lowest value
// and points[points.length-1] contains the highest value

content.code_html:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return a - b});
// now points[0] contains the lowest value
 // and points[points.length-1] contains the highest value

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // now points[0] contains the lowest value
// and points[points.length-1] contains the highest value

content.text: Sort Descending:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // now points[0] contains the highest value
// and points[points.length-1] contains the lowest value

syntax_highlighting.text: // now points[0] contains the highest value
// and points[points.length-1] contains the lowest value

content.code_html:
const points = [40, 100, 1, 5, 25, 10];
points.sort(function(a, b){return b - a});
// now points[0] contains the highest value
 // and points[points.length-1] contains the lowest value

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // now points[0] contains the highest value
// and points[points.length-1] contains the lowest value

content.text: Note
Sorting a whole array is a very inefficient method if you only want to find the highest (or lowest) value.
content.html: Sorting a whole array is a very inefficient method if you only want to find the highest (or lowest) value.

content.text: Using Math.min() on an Array
You can use Math.min.apply to find the lowest number in an array:
content.html: You can use Math.min.apply to find the lowest number in an array:

content.code_html:
function myArrayMin(arr) {
  return Math.min.apply(null, arr);
}

content.text: Math.min.apply(null, [1, 2, 3]) is equivalent to Math.min(1, 2, 3) .
content.html: Math.min.apply(null, [1, 2, 3]) is equivalent to Math.min(1, 2, 3).

content.text: Using Math.max() on an Array
You can use Math.max.apply to find the highest number in an array:
content.html: You can use Math.max.apply to find the highest number in an array:

content.code_html:
function myArrayMax(arr) {
  return Math.max.apply(null, arr);
}

content.text: Math.max.apply(null, [1, 2, 3]) is equivalent to Math.max(1, 2, 3) .
content.html: Math.max.apply(null, [1, 2, 3]) is equivalent to Math.max(1, 2, 3).

content.text: JavaScript Array Minimum Method
There is no built-in function for finding the lowest value in a JavaScript array.
content.html: There is no built-in function for finding the lowest value in a JavaScript array.

content.text: The fastest code to find the lowest number is to use a home made method.
content.html: The fastest code to find the lowest number is to use a home made method.

content.text: This function loops through an array comparing each value with the lowest value found:
content.html: This function loops through an array comparing each value with the lowest value found:

content.code_html:
function myArrayMin(arr) {
  let len = arr.length;
  let min = Infinity;
  while (len--) {
    if (arr[len] < min) {
      min = arr[len];
    }
  }
  return min;
}

content.text: JavaScript Array Maximum Method
There is no built-in function for finding the highest value in a JavaScript array.
content.html: There is no built-in function for finding the highest value in a JavaScript array.

content.text: The fastest code to find the highest number is to use a home made method.
content.html: The fastest code to find the highest number is to use a home made method.

content.text: This function loops through an array comparing each value with the highest value found:
content.html: This function loops through an array comparing each value with the highest value found:

content.code_html:
function myArrayMax(arr) {
  let len = arr.length;
  let max = -Infinity;
  while (len--) {
    if (arr[len] > max) {
      max = arr[len];
    }
  }
  return max;
}

content.text: Sorting Object Arrays
JavaScript arrays often contain objects:
content.html: JavaScript arrays often contain objects:

content.code_html:
const cars = [
  {type:"Volvo", year:2016},
  {type:"Saab", year:2001},
  {type:"BMW", year:2010}
];

content.text: Even if objects have properties of different data types, the sort() method can be used to sort the array.
content.html: Even if objects have properties of different data types, the sort() method can be used to sort the array.

content.text: The solution is to write a compare function to compare the property values:
content.html: The solution is to write a compare function to compare the property values:

content.code_html: cars.sort(function(a, b){return a.year - b.year});

content.text: Comparing string properties is a little more complex:
content.html: Comparing string properties is a little more complex:

content.code_html:
cars.sort(function(a, b){
  let x = a.type.toLowerCase();
  let y = b.type.toLowerCase();
  if (x < y) {return -1;}
  if (x > y) {return 1;}
  return 0;
});

content.text: Stable Array sort()
ES2019 revised the Array sort() method.
content.html: ES2019 revised the Array sort() method.

content.text: Before 2019, the specification allowed unstable sorting algorithms such as QuickSort.
content.html: Before 2019, the specification allowed unstable sorting algorithms such as QuickSort.

content.text: After ES2019, browsers must use a stable sorting algorithm:
content.html: After ES2019, browsers must use a stable sorting algorithm:

content.text: When sorting elements on a value, the elements must keep their relative position to other elements with the same value.
content.html: When sorting elements on a value, the elements must keep their relative position to other elements with the same value.

content.code_html:
const myArr = [
  {name:"X00",price:100 },
  {name:"X01",price:100 },
  {name:"X02",price:100 },
  {name:"X03",price:100 },
  {name:"X04",price:110 },
  {name:"X05",price:110 },
  {name:"X06",price:110 },
  {name:"X07",price:110 }
];

content.text: In the example above, when sorting on price, the result is not allowed to come out with the names in an other relative position like this:
content.html: In the example above, when sorting on price, the result is not allowed to come out with the names in an other relative position like this:

content.code_html:
X01 100
X03 100
X00 100
X03 100
X05 110
X04 110
X06 110
X07 110

content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Array properties and methods.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: const fruits = ['Apple', 'Orange', 'Banana']; fruits.reverse(); What will the result of the fruits array?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
const fruits = ['Apple', 'Orange', 'Banana'];
fruits.reverse();
What will the result of the fruits array?
